item.title: IIT Madras Online Degree
item.dc:creator: KHUSHI
item.description: Joining IIT Madras Online Degree Program: A Comprehensive Guide   IIT Madras offers a transformative opportunity through its online degree programs, designed for both current Class 12 students and graduates, without any age restrictions. This guide presents a step-by-step process to join the program via the official website. Here’s why you should consider this incredible… Read More »IIT Madras Online Degree
item.content:encoded:
Joining IIT Madras Online Degree Program: A Comprehensive Guide

 

IIT Madras offers a transformative opportunity through its online degree programs, designed for both current Class 12 students and graduates, without any age restrictions. This guide presents a step-by-step process to join the program via the official website. Here’s why you should consider this incredible opportunity:

 

1. Eligibility and Multiple Reattempts:

Whether you’re a Class 12 student or a graduate, there’s no age limit to join IIT Madras’ online degree program. The entry barrier is set at a minimum of 40% marks in each of the four subjects: Mathematics, Computer Technology (CT), Statistics, and English. In IIT Madras Own Qualifier Exam .Furthermore, the program allows for multiple reattempts, ensuring you have ample opportunities to succeed. Through JEE You Can Take Direct Entry

 

2. Affordable Fees:

The first year of the program comes at an exceptionally low cost – just 4000 per course. This affordability opens doors for aspiring learners from all walks of life to access a prestigious education from one of India’s top institutions.

 

3. Why Choose IIT Madras Online Degree :

IIT Madras boasts the highest NIRF ranking, standing as a testament to its academic excellence and commitment to providing top-notch education. By enrolling in this online degree program, you align yourself with a prestigious institution known for producing top talents across various fields.

 

4. Quality Facilities and Instruction:

Studying at IIT Madras means you’ll have access to world-class facilities and resources. All lectures are conducted in English, ensuring that language is not a barrier to your learning. The faculty consists of renowned experts who are passionate about imparting knowledge and guiding your academic journey.

 

5. Campus Visit and Paradox Event:

Once a year, you have the exciting opportunity to visit the IIT Madras campus during the “Paradox” event – the largest student community gathering that spans 4-5 days. This event draws students from all over India, offering a vibrant platform to engage in various sports, functions, and innovative events like Hack-O-Pitch. It’s a chance to immerse yourself in the rich cultural and academic environment of IIT Madras.

 

Step-by-Step Guide to Joining:

 

Step 1: Visit the Official Website:

Start by accessing the official IIT Madras website. Navigate to the dedicated section for online degree programs.

 

Step 2: Explore Programs Like DS Or ES and Choose Your Path:

Browse through the array of online degree programs offered. Each program has specific requirements and courses tailored to various disciplines. Choose the one that aligns with your academic and career aspirations.

 

Step 3: Verify Eligibility:

Ensure you meet the eligibility criteria – Passed Or At Class 12

 

Step 4: Online Registration:

Click on the provided registration link. Fill in accurate personal and educational information. Make sure to provide a valid email address for future communications.

 

Step 5: Document Submission:

Upload clear, scanned copies of essential documents such as educational certificates, identity proof, and photographs.

 

Step 6: Fee Payment Basically This Step Occurs Before Documents Sumission :

Pay the registration fee, which is kept affordable at 4000 per course for the first year. Payment options will be available online , And or Qualifiers Or Joining Fees 3000 For A Month .

 

Step 7: Select Your Courses:

After confirming registration and fee payment, log in to your account. Choose the courses you wish to enroll in for the upcoming semester. Read course descriptions and prerequisites carefully.

 

Step 8: Access Learning Materials:

Upon enrolling in courses, gain access to the online learning platform. Here, find lecture videos, assignments, resources, and announcements.

 

Step 9: Engage and Learn:

Actively participate in courses, engage with course content, complete assignments, and interact with peers through online discussions.

 

Step 10: Reattempt for Success:

If needed, utilize the option of multiple reattempts to improve your performance and understanding.

 

Conclusion:

Enrolling in IIT Madras’ online degree program is an opportunity that opens doors to a world of academic excellence, enriched learning, and valuable experiences. With the step-by-step guide provided here, you’re equipped to embark on a journey that combines flexibility, affordability, and top-notch education from India’s finest institution. Don’t miss out on the chance to be part of IIT Madras’ legacy and to experience the campus’s vibrancy through the annual Paradox event. Your future awaits – take the first step today!

item.title: BS In Electronic System WhatsApp Group Link
item.dc:creator: KHUSHI
item.description: Join Subject-Wise  Bs In Electronic System IIT Madras : A Comprehensive Guide to Applying for IIT Madras ES Degree Online Introduction: The Electronic System  (ES) at IIT Madras opens doors to a world of knowledge and career advancement .Check Below Link To ensure you stay well-informed and connected throughout your application process, this guide introduces subject-wise… Read More »BS In Electronic System WhatsApp Group Link
item.content:encoded:
Join Subject-Wise  Bs In Electronic System IIT Madras : A Comprehensive Guide to Applying for IIT Madras ES Degree Online

Introduction:

The Electronic System  (ES) at IIT Madras opens doors to a world of knowledge and career advancement .Check Below Link To ensure you stay well-informed and connected throughout your application process, this guide introduces subject-wise WhatsApp groups. These groups serve as platforms for sharing insights, clarifying doubts, and receiving support from like-minded individuals.

Joining the WhatsApp Groups Engaging with these groups is a straightforward process:

  1. Visit the IIT Madras Students Community Page: Access the official IITM Students Community webpage to find the links to the subject-wise WhatsApp groups.

  2. Select a Group: Click on the link that corresponds to your academic background and interests.

  3. Join the Group: Upon clicking the link, you’ll be redirected to WhatsApp. Click “Join Group” to become a member.

  4. Introduce Yourself: Once in the group, introduce yourself briefly. Share a snapshot of your educational background and your motivation for pursuing the Online Electronic System Degree.

Step 4: Active Engagement and Contribution Actively participate in the group discussions. Pose questions, share your insights, and benefit from the collective wisdom of your fellow applicants. Remember, these groups provide a unique networking opportunity and a chance to gain diverse perspectives.

Step 5: Application Process Insights While these WhatsApp groups are an invaluable resource for peer interaction, remember to cross-reference crucial application details from official IIT Madras sources, emails, and the application portal for the most accurate information.

Step 6: Cultivating a Positive Environment Ensure that your contributions to the WhatsApp groups are constructive and respectful. Avoid excessive promotion or sharing unrelated content.

Step 7: Doubt Resolution and Networking Leverage the WhatsApp groups to clarify doubts related to the application process or the Online Electronic System Degree program. Fellow group members and even program representatives might offer valuable insights.

Conclusion: Subject-wise WhatsApp groups established by the IITM Students Community are a fantastic way to connect with like-minded peers while pursuing the Online Electronic System Degree from IIT Madras. Active participation will broaden your knowledge, provide valuable insights, and offer the support you need throughout the application journey. Remember, these groups complement official communications and information from IIT Madras and should not replace official sources. Best of luck as you embark on your academic pursuit!

Click here

If Having Problem To Understand Below Full Video Is Also Given  Title: A Step-by-Step Guide to Applying for IIT Madras Executive Master’s in ES Degree Online Introduction:Pursuing higher education is a significant milestone in… Read More »How To Apply For Bs In Electronic System IIT Madras
item.content:encoded:
Hii In This Blog Full Steps Are Given How To Apply For Electronic System At IIT Madras 2023 From Registration Form. If Having Problem To Understand Below Full Video Is Also Given 

Title: A Step-by-Step Guide to Applying for IIT Madras Executive Master’s in ES Degree Online

Introduction:
Pursuing higher education is a significant milestone in one’s career journey. If you’re aiming to advance your expertise in Environmental Sustainability (ES), the Executive Master’s program at IIT Madras is an excellent choice. This blog post serves as a comprehensive guide to help you navigate through the application process for the IIT Madras ES Degree online.

Step 1: Research and Program Evaluation
Begin by thoroughly Online Degree the Executive Master’s in ES program offered by IIT Madras. Understand the curriculum, course structure, faculty, and the unique features that make this program stand out.

Step 2: Eligibility Check
Ensure that you meet the eligibility criteria for the program. Passed Class 12 Or At Class 12 

Step 3: Online Application Portal
Visit the official IIT Madras website and locate the online application portal for the ES Degree program. Create an account or log in if you already have one.

Step 4: Fill Out Personal Information
Provide your personal details such as name, date of birth, contact information, and address. Make sure all the information is accurate and up to date.

Step 5: Academic and Professional Details
Enter details about your educational background, including degrees obtained, institutions attended, and relevant certifications. Include information about your professional experience, highlighting roles related to environmental sustainability.

Step 6: Statement of Purpose (SOP)
Write a compelling Statement of Purpose that outlines your reasons for pursuing the ES Degree at IIT Madras. Explain your career goals, how this program aligns with your aspirations, and what you hope to contribute to the field.

Step 7: Letters of Recommendation
Provide contact details of individuals who can write letters of recommendation for you. These should be professionals who can attest to your academic abilities, work ethics, and potential for success in the program.

Step 8: Upload Documents
Upload scanned copies of your academic transcripts, certificates, passport-sized photograph, and any other documents requested by the application portal.

Step 9: Application Fee [Basically This Step Occurs Before Documents Submitting] 
Pay the application fee 6000 as specified in the guidelines. Keep the payment confirmation receipt for future reference And Its Free For JEE Students .

Step 10: Review and Submit
Before submitting, carefully review all the information you’ve entered and the documents you’ve uploaded. Ensure accuracy and completeness.

Step 11: Submission Confirmation
After successfully submitting your application, you should receive a confirmation email. This email may contain further instructions or information about the selection process.

Step 12: Selection Process
The IIT Madras admissions committee will review all applications and shortlist candidates for further rounds, which might include interviews or additional assessments.

Conclusion:
Check Out Full Screenshot With Detailed Video Below If Having Doubt Anymore  !

https://study.iitm.ac.in/es/

 

Detailed Video Solution on How To Apply For IIT Madras Bs Degree In Electronic

Join WhatsApp Group For Electronic System

The amount of milk produced every day by a dairy is uniformly distributed between 100100 litres and 120120 litres. What is the probability that the amount of milk produced is more than 118118 litres given that on that day, more than 109109 litres of milk was produced? If 55 persons arrived at the restaurant then what is the probability that at least 22 of them will be served in more than 77 minutes? (Assume that each person is served independently)

In a certain exhibition, the time for the next visitor to come is exponentially distributed with a standard deviation of 1111 minutes. What will be the expected time (in minutes) for two visitors to arrive if one comes after the other? (Note that the arrival of a visitor is independent of the arrival of the previous visitor.)

A match predictor claims that he can predict the result of a match correctly 77% of the time. It is agreed that his claim will be accepted if he correctly predicts the results of at least 4 of 8 matches. What is the probability that his claim gets rejected?
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 

 

 
1 point
 
If �∼��������(�,�)X∼Binomial(n,p), then which of the following statement/s is/are always true? (�>0n>0 and 0<�<10<p<1)
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 

 

 
 
 
Two friends (say ‘�A‘ and ‘�B‘) could not decide whether to play a racing game or a boxing game on Xbox. They decide to play a card-game first. If ‘�A‘ wins at least 3 rounds out of the 5 rounds of the card game played, then the boxing game will be played. The chances of ‘�A‘ winning in any round of the card game is 2:5. Find the probability that the boxing game will be played on Xbox? (Enter the answer correct to 2 decimal places)
Hint: If the chances of happening of an event is x:y then, the probability equals ��+�x+yx
 
 
1 point
 

 

 
 
 
Let �X~ Binomial(6,p). If the probabilities of 4 and 5 successes are approximately 0.311 and, 0.1866 respectively, then find the parameter ‘p’ of the distribution.(Enter the answer correct to 2 decimal places)
 
 
1 point
 

 

 
 
 
If the expected number of sixes hit by a batsman on �n balls is 6.39 and the variance for the same is 1.8531, then what is the probability of him hitting at least one six on any randomly selected �n balls? Assume that the probability of him hitting a six on any ball is constant. (Enter the answer correct to 4 decimal places)
 
 
1 point
 

 

 
 
 
The probability of a student clearing a competitive exam is 1441. If he gives the exam 6 times, then what is the probability of him clearing the exam at least twice?(Enter the answer correct to 2 decimal places)
 
 
1 point
 

 

 
1 point
Choose the correct condition/s about binomial distribution.
 
 
 
 
 

 

 
 
 
Rithika wants to test whether the coin she has is a fair coin or not. To test this, she conducted an experiment of tossing the coin 5 times. Binomial random variable �X is defined as the total number of heads(�i) after 5 tosses. The probability distribution of the binomial random variable is given in Table 11.1.G.
�=�X=i�(�=�)P(X=i)
00.00032
10.0064
20.0512
30.2048
40.4096
50.32768
Table 11.1.G: Binomial Distribution
What is the approximate probability of getting a head in tossing the given coin? (Enter the answer correct to one decimal place)
 
 
1 point
 

 

 
 
1 point
At a school function, It is noticed that 9% of the students are not wearing polished shoes and 12% of students are not wearing school ties. It is announced that the students who have committed any of the infractions will be punished, and that these two infractions are independent of one another. If a teacher selects 5 students at random, then find the probability that exactly three of the students will be punished for any of the infractions?
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 

 

 
 
1 point
There are 7 black and 20 blue pens in a box. A pen is chosen at random, and its colour is noted. If the process repeats independently, 13 times with replacement, then calculate the expected number of black pens chosen?
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 

 

 
Number of calls received at an office follows a Poisson distribution with an average of 1 call per minute. Find the probability that no call will be received in two minutes at the office. (Enter the answer correct to 2 decimal accuracy.)
 
1 point

 

A quiz team is to be chosen randomly from 6 boys and 4 girls. The team has 3 slots which are to be filled randomly. If �X denotes the number of boys in the quiz team, then using the given information, answer questions (12) and (13).
 
 
Calculate �(�=2)P(X=2). (Enter the answer correct to 2 decimal places)
 
 
1 point
 
 
Calculate the value of �(�)E(X). (Enter the answer correct to 2 decimal places)

1. An undirected graph G has 26 vertices and the degree of each vertex is at least 6. What is the minimum number of edges that the graph G can have?
 
 
1 point
 

 

 
 
2. If G is a connected undirected graph such that every vertex has degree at most 9 , and the shortest path between any two vertices has length at most 2, then what is the maximum number of vertices in G? (Hint: Try to draw the BFS tree starting with any vertex)

1 point

item.content:encoded:
Computational Thinking week 11 graded assignment Complete  Questions Are Discussed In This Blog.  Access From Below Link

1.reverse is a recursive procedure to reverse a list. Select the correct code fragment to complete the pseudocode given below. It is a Multiple Select Question (MSQ).



 
 
 
 
1
Procedure reverse(L)
2
    if(length(L) <= 1){
3
        return(L)
4
    }
5
     *********************
6
      * Fill the code *
7
     *********************
8
End reverse
9
 
 

 

 

return([last(L)] ++ reverse(init(L)))

return([first(L)] ++ reverse(rest(L)))

return([last(L)] ++ reverse(init(rest(L))) ++ [first(L)])

return([first(L)] ++ reverse(init(rest(L))) ++ [last(L)])

return([last(L)] ++ reverse(rest(init(L))) ++ [first(L)])

 
 

 

Question:2-4:

An auto-grading system for an online course is designed in the following way:

∙∙ A student’s submission is recorded as a dictionary with the following keys 
           ∘∘  The “roll” key maps to the student’s roll number.
           ∘∘  The “time” key maps to the time of submission
           ∘∘  The “score” key maps to the student’s score for that submission

∙  ∙  Each student can make multiple submissions before the deadline.  
∙  ∙  Every time a student makes a submission, the dictionary corresponding to it is appended to the end of a list called scores.

An example:

  

 
 
 
 
 
1
scores =   [{“roll”: 12, “time”: 10:20, “score”: 80 },
2
            {“roll”: 20, “time”: 11:23, “score”: 70 },
3
            {“roll”: 12, “time”: 20:40, “score”: 90 },
4
            {“roll”: 12, “time”: 23:50, “score”: 95 },
5
            {“roll”: 20, “time”: 23:53, “score”: 65 }]
 
 


Study the following pseudocode:

 
 
 
 
 
1
Procedure isPresent(L, roll)
2
    foreach D in L{
3
        if(D[“roll”] == roll){
4
            return(True)
5
        }
6
    }
7
    return(False)
8
End isPresent
 
 


 
 
 
 
 
1
Procedure getSubs(L)
2
    firstSub = {}, restSub = []
3
    if(length(L) <= 1){
4
        return(L)
5
    }
6
    firstSub = first(L)
7
    restSub = rest(L)
8
    if(isPresent(restSub, firstSub[“roll”])){
9
        return(getSubs(restSub))
10
    }
11
    else {
12
        return([firstSub] ++ getSubs(restSub))
13
    }
14
End getSubs
 
 


Answer questions 2 to 4 after executing the pseudocode given below:
 
 
 
 
 
1
submisssions = []
2
3
scores = [ {“roll”: 12, “time”: 10:20, “score”: 80 },
4
           {“roll”: 20, “time”: 11:23, “score”: 70 },
5
           {“roll”: 12, “time”: 20:40, “score”: 90 },
6
           {“roll”: 12, “time”: 23:50, “score”: 95 },
7
           {“roll”: 20, “time”: 23:53, “score”: 65 } ]
8
9
submisssions = getSubs(scores)
 
 
 
 
 
4 points

2. What is the value of submissions?

[ {“roll”: 12, “time”: 10:20, “score”: 80 },

{“roll”: 20, “time”: 11:23, “score”: 70 } ]

[ {“roll”: 20, “time”: 11:23, “score”: 70 },

{“roll”: 12, “time”: 10:20, “score”: 80 } ]

[ {“roll”: 12, “time”: 23:50, “score”: 95 },

{“roll”: 20, “time”: 23:53, “score”: 65 } ]

[ {“roll”: 20, “time”: 23:53, “score”: 65 },

{“roll”: 12, “time”: 23:50, “score”: 95 } ]

 
 
4 points

3.What does the variable submissions represent?

The list of all the submissions made by the students sorted in the ascending order of time.

The list of all the submissions made by the students sorted in the descending order of time.

The list of the last submissions made by the students sorted in the ascending order of time.

The list of the last submissions made by the students sorted in the descending order of time.

The list of the first submissions made by the students sorted in the ascending order of time.

The list of the first submissions made by the students sorted in the descending order of time.

 
 
4 points

4.Assume that reverse is a procedure that reverses a list. Which of the following statements returns the list of the first submissions made by the students sorted in the ascending order of time?

getSubs(scores)

reverse(getSubs(scores))

getSubs(reverse(scores)))

reverse(getSubs(reverse(scores)))

 
 

 

 
 
4 points
 

5.outcomes is a list of strings that contains the information about the outcome of cricket matches played by India in a tournament. Assume that each element in the list is either “win” or “loss”. For example, if five matches have been played, then outcomes could look like this:

[“won”, “lost”, “lost”, “won”, “won”]

We call a list of outcomes a blank slate if the number of wins is equal to the number of losses. blankSlate is a procedure that accepts outcomes as input and returns True if it is a blank slate and False otherwise. Select the correct code fragment to complete the following pseudocode. It is a Multiple Select Question (MSQ).

 
 
 
 
1
Procedure blankSlate(outcomes)
2
    if(numeric(outcomes) == 0){
3
        return(True)
4
    }
5
    else{
6
        return(False)
7
    }
8
End blankSlate
9
10
*********************
11
* Fill the code *
12
*********************
 
 

 

 
 
 
 
 
 
 
1
Procedure numeric(L)
2
    if(length(L) == 0){
3
        return(0)
4
    }
5
    if(last(L) == “won”){
6
        return(numeric(init(L)) + 1)
7
    }
8
    else{
9
        return(numeric(init(L)) − 1)
10
    }
11
End numeric
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
1
Procedure numeric(L)
2
    if(length(L) == 0){
3
        return (0)
4
    }
5
    if(last(L) == “won”){
6
        return(numeric(rest(L)) + 1)
7
    }
8
    else{
9
        return(numeric(rest(L)) − 1)
10
    }
11
End numeric
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
1
Procedure numeric(L)
2
    if(length(L) == 0){
3
        return(0)
4
    }
5
    if(first(L) == “won”){
6
        return(numeric(rest(L)) + 1)
7
    }
8
    else{
9
        return(numeric(rest(L)) − 1)
10
    }
11
End numeric
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
1
Procedure numeric(L)
2
    if(length(L) == 0){
3
        return(0)
4
    }
5
    if(first(L) == “won”){
6
        return(numeric(init(L)) + 1)
7
    }
8
    else{
9
        return(numeric(init(L)) − 1)
10
    }
11
End numeric
 
 
 
 
 

 

QUESTION-6-7

2n chess players are participating in a tournament. Each player is given a unique participant ID that is represented as a string. The player IDs are stored in a non-empty list players in the descending order of their rating, i.e., the first element in the list has the ID of the player with the highest rating.

The matches are scheduled as follows: The ��ℎith match is between the ��ℎith player from the top and the ��ℎith player from the bottom of the rating list. We wish to create a list called matches which stores the sequences of matches, starting with the first match and ending with the last match. Each match is represented as a list of two players, the first element of which is the ID of the player with the higher rating, while the second element is the ID of the player with lower rating. Assume that no two players have the same rating.

Answer questions 6 and 7 based on this information.

 
4 points

matchThem is a recursive procedure that accepts players as argument and returns matches. Select the correct implementation of the procedure. It is a Multiple Select Question (MSQ).

 
 
 
 
 
 
1
Procedure matchThem(players)
2
    firstLast = [], middle = []
3
    if(length(players) == 2){
4
        return([players])
5
    }
6
    else{
7
        firstLast = [first(players), last(players)]
8
        middle = init(rest(players))
9
        return([firstLast] ++ matchThem(middle))
10
    }
11
End matchThem
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
1
Procedure matchThem(players)
2
    firstLast = [], middle = []
3
    if(length(players) == 2){
4
        return(players)
5
    }
6
    else{
7
        firstLast = [first(players), last(players)]
8
        middle = init(rest(players))
9
        return([firstLast] ++ matchThem(middle))
10
    }
11
End matchThem
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
1
Procedure matchThem(players)
2
    firstLast = [], middle = []
3
    if(length(players) == 0){
4
        return([])
5
    }
6
    else{
7
        firstLast = [first(players), last(players)]
8
        middle = init(rest(players))
9
        return([firstLast] ++ matchThem(middle))
10
    }
11
End matchThem
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
1
Procedure matchThem(players)
2
    firstLast = [], middle = []
3
    if(length(players) == 0){
4
        return([players])
5
    }
6
    else{
7
        firstLast = [first(players), last(players)]
8
        middle = init(rest(players))
9
        return([firstLast] ++ matchThem(middle))
10
    }
11
End matchThem
 
 
 
 
 
3 points

7.matchThem is a non-recursive procedure that accepts players as argument and returns matches. Select the correct implementation of the procedure.

 
 
 
 
 
 
1
Procedure matchThem(players)
2
    matches = [ ]
3
    while(length(players) > 0){
4
        matches = matches ++ [[last(players), first(players)]]
5
        players = rest(init(players))
6
    }
7
    return(matches)
8
End matchThem
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
1
Procedure matchThem(players)
2
    matches = [ ]
3
    while(length(players) > 0){
4
        matches = matches ++ [[first(players), last(players)]]
5
        players = rest(init(players))
6
    }
7
    return(matches)
8
End matchThem
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
1
Procedure matchThem(players)
2
    matches = [ ]
3
    while(length(players) >= 0){
4
        matches = matches ++ [[first(players), last(players)]]
5
        players = rest(init(players))
6
    }
7
    return(matches)
8
End matchThem
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
1
Procedure matchThem(players)
2
    matches = [ ]
3
    while(length(players) > 0){
4
        matches = matches ++ [[first(players), last(players)]]
5
        players = rest(players)
6
    }
7
    return(matches)
8
End matchThem
9
 
 
 
 
 
 

 

Question 8-11

Consider the following graph with six nodes. A is a 6 × 6 matrix corresponding to this graph. Assume that it has already been computed:

In the following pseudocode:

  • graph is a matrix
  • parents is a dictionary
  • sequence is a list
 
 
 
 
 
1
Procedure DFS(graph, parents, sequence, i)
2
    sequence = sequence ++ [i]
3
    foreach j in columns(graph){
4
        if(graph[i][j] == 1 and not(isKey(parents, j))){
5
            parents[j] = i
6
            parents, sequence = DFS(graph, parents, sequence, j)
7
        }
8
    }
9
    return(parents, sequence)
10
End DFS
 
 


Answer questions 8 to 11 using the information given above. In all questions, S represents a list, P represents a dictionary, while A and B represent matrices.
 
4 points
 

8.What will be the value of S after executing the following pseudocode?

 
 
 
 
1
P = { }
2
S = [ ]
3
P[0] = -1
4
P, S = DFS(A, P, S, 0)
 
 

 

 

[0, 1, 2, 5, 3, 4]

[0, 1, 4]

[0, 1, 2, 3, 5, 4]

[0, 3, 1, 4, 5]

 
 
3 points
 

9.What will be the value of nodes after executing the following pseudocode?

 
 
 
 
1
P = { }
2
S = [ ], nodes = []
3
P[5] = -1
4
P, S = DFS(A, P, S, 5)
5
nodes = keys(P)
 
 

 

 

[5, 2, 1, 0, 3, 4]

[5, 2, 1, 4, 0, 3]

[5, 2, 3, 0, 1, 4]

Cannot be determined

 
 
3 points
 

10.Assume that sort is a procedure that accepts a list of integers as input and returns a sorted list in ascending order. If 0 ≤ start ≤ 5, which of the following statements are true at the end of execution of the following pseudocode? It is a Multiple Select Question (MSQ).

 
 
 
 
1
P = { }
2
S = [], nodes = []
3
P[start] = -1
4
P, S = DFS(A, P, S, start)
5
nodes = sort(keys(P))
 
 

 

 

nodes is equal to [0, 1, 2, 3, 4, 5]

S is equal to [0, 1, 2, 3, 4, 5]

The value of nodes is independent of start

The value of S is independent of start

The graph is connected.

The graph is not connected.

 
 
4 points
 

11.Execute the following pseudocode

 
 
 
 
1
P = { }
2
S = [ ]
3
P[3] = -1, parent = 0
4
P, S = DFS(A, P, S, 3)
5
B = createMatrix(6, 6)
6
foreach i in keys(P){
7
    if(i != 3){
8
        parent = P[i]
9
        B[parent][i] = 1
10
    }
11
}

item.content:encoded:
Statistics Week 10 graded assignment Complete  Solutions Key Given In This Page Check Below . We Hope This Might Help You All In Matching Answers . Or For Some Others Reasons If Not Able To Complete Graded Assignments 

 
There are 2626numbered cards in a deck among which 6��6Ci cards bear the number �;�=0,1,2,...,6i;i=0,1,2,…,6. From the deck, 10 cards are drawn with replacement. What is the expectation of the sum of their numbers?(Enter the answer correct to 1 decimal accuracy)
1 point


1 point
An unbiased die is thrown 13 times. After each throw a ‘+’ is recorded for 2 or 5 and ‘-‘ is recorded for 1,3,4 or 6, the signs forming an ordered sequence. To each, except the first and last sign, a random variable ��;�=1,2,...,11Xi;i=1,2,…,11 is associated which takes the value 11 if both of its neighbouring sign differs from the one between them and 00 otherwise. If the random variable �Y is defined as �=3�+13Y=3S+13 where, �=∑�=111��S=∑i=111Xi.
Find the expected value of �Y.
1 point
An unbiased die is thrown 13 times. After each throw a ‘+’ is recorded for 2 or 5 and ‘-‘ is recorded for 1,3,4 or 6, the signs forming an ordered sequence. To each, except the first and last sign, a random variable ��;�=1,2,...,11Xi;i=1,2,…,11 is associated which takes the value 11 if both of its neighbouring sign differs from the one between them and 00 otherwise. If the random variable �Y is defined as �=3�+13Y=3S+13 where, �=∑�=111��S=∑i=111Xi.
Which of the following statement(s) is/are true?



1 point
Amandeep is in the middle of a bridge of infinite length. He takes the unit step to the right with probability 0.66 and to the left with probability 0.34. Assume that the movements are independent of each other.
Hint: Consider the random variable ��Xi associated with the ��ℎith step defined as:
��Xi={1if the step of Amandeep is towards the right −1if the step of Amandeep is towards the left {1−1if the step of Amandeep is towards the right if the step of Amandeep is towards the left 
What is the expected distance between the starting point and end point of Amandeep after 5 steps?
1 point
Amandeep is in the middle of a bridge of infinite length. He takes the unit step to the right with probability 0.66 and to the left with probability 0.34. Assume that the movements are independent of each other.
Hint: Consider the random variable ��Xi associated with the ��ℎith step defined as:
��Xi={1if the step of Amandeep is towards the right −1if the step of Amandeep is towards the left {1−1if the step of Amandeep is towards the right if the step of Amandeep is towards the left 
What is the variance distance between the starting point and end point of Amandeep after 5 steps?


A box contains 10 white and 6 black balls. 2 balls are drawn at random without replacement. Find the expected value of the number of white balls drawn. (Enter the answer correct to 2 decimal places)
1 point



1 point
Rohit wants to open his door with 55 keys(out of which 11 will open the door) and tries the keys independently and at random. If unsuccessful keys are eliminated from further selection, then Find the expected number of trials required to open the door.
Hint: Suppose Rohit gets the first success at ��ℎxth trial, i.e., he is unable to open the door in the first (�−1)(x−1) trials.
And, P(he gets first success at second trial)=(1−15)×14(1−51)×41


�X and �Y are independent random variables with means 14 and 20, and variances 2 and 6 respectively. Find the variance of 3�+6�3X+6Y.
1 point


Table Q10.1.G. represents the probability mass function of a random variable X
�X-145
�(�=�)P(X=x)16611331918189
Table Q10.1.G: Probability Mass Function
Calculate the value of �(2�+1)2E(2X+1)2. (Enter the answer correct to 2 decimal places)
1 point


1 point
Suppose that �X is a random variable for which �(�)=15E(X)=15 and ���(�)=22Var(X)=22. Find the positive values of �a and �b such that �=��−�Y=aX−b, has expectation 00 and variance 11.

item.content:encoded:
Computational Thinking week 10 graded assignment Complete  Solutions Are Discussed In This Blog. We Hope This Might Help You All In Matching Answers . Or For Some Others Reasons If Not Able To Complete Graded Assignments 

1.The following pseudocode is executing using the “Scores” table. At the end of the execution, matrix represents the adjacency matrix of the graph generated from the “Scores” table.

 
 
 
 
1
D = {}
2
while(Table 1 has more rows){
3
    Read the first row X in Table 1
4
    D[X.SeqNo] = {"P": X.Physics, "C": X.Chemistry, "M": X.Mathematics}
5
    Move X to Table 2
6
}
7
matrixPh = getAdjMatrix(D, "P")
8
matrixCh = getAdjMatrix(D, "C")
9
matrixMa = getAdjMatrix(D, "M")
10
11
Procedure getAdjMatrix(D, Subject)
12
    n = length(keys(D))
13
    matrix = createMatrix(n, n)
14
    foreach i in rows(matrix){
15
        foreach j in columns(matrix){
16
            if(i != j){
17
                diff = D[i][Subject] - D[j][Subject]
18
                if(10 <= diff and diff <= 20){
19
                    matrix[i][j] = 1
20
                }
21
            }
22
        }
23
    }
24
    return(matrix)
25
End getAdjMatrix
 
 

 

 
5 points

If matrixPh[i] [j] = 1, then

i scored at most 10 and at least 20 more marks in Physics than j

 

i scored at least 10 and at most 20 more marks in Physics than j

 

j scored at least 10 and at most 20 more marks in Physics than i

 

j scored at most 10 and at least 20 more marks in Physics than i

 

 
 
5 points
2.Choose the correct statement based on above pseudocode.

 

For all i, j with i 

≠

= j, matrixPh[i][j] + matrixPh[j][i] = 1

 

 

 

For all i, j with i 

≠

= j, if matrixPh[i][j] = 1 then matrixPh[j][i] = 0

 

 

 

For all i, j with i 

≠

= j, if matrixPh[i][j] = 0 then matrixPh[j][i] = 1

 

 

 

For all i, j with i 

≠

= j, if matrixPh[i][j] = 1 then matrixPh[j][i] = 1

 

 

 

For all i, j with i 

≠

= j, if matrixPh[i][j] = 0 then matrixPh[j][i] = 0

 

 

 
 
5 points
 

3.Consider the dictionary D, and the matrices matrixPh, matrixCh and matrixMa computed in the previous question. The following pseudocode generate the adjacency matrix matrixHelp.

 
 
 
 
1
n = length(keys(D))
2
matrixHelp = createMatrix(n, n)
3
    foreach i in rows(matrixHelp){
4
        foreach j in columns(matrixHelp){
5
            matrixHelp[i][j] = matrixCh[i][j] + matrixPh[i][j] + matrixMa[i][j]
6
        }
7
}
 
 

 

Let i and j be indices of two students. Choose the correct statement(s) from the given options. It is a Multiple Select Question (MSQ)

 

0 <= matrixHelp[i][j] <= 3

 

matrixHelp[i][j] + matrixHelp[j][i] <= 3

 

 

matrixHelp[i][j] 

≠

= matrixHelp[j][i]

 

 

if matrixHelp[i][j] = 0, then matrixHelp[j][i] = 3

 

if matrixHelp[i][j] = 3, then matrixHelp[j][i] = 0

 

 
 
5 points
 

4.At the end of the following pseudocode, A captures the number of distinct pairs of students who can help each other in at least one subject, and B captures the number of distinct pairs of students where one can help the other in all subjects. Choose the correct code fragment to complete the pseudocode.

 
 
 
 
1
A = 0, B = 0
2
foreach i in rows(matrixHelp){
3
    foreach j in columns(matrixHelp){
4
        ***********************
5
         *** Fill the code ***
6
        ***********************
7
    }
8
}
9
 
 

 

 

 

 
 
 
 
 
1
if(matrixHelp[i][j] > 0 and matrixHelp[j][i] > 0){
2
    A = A + 1
3
}
4
if(matrixHelp[i][j] == 3){
5
    B = B + 1
6
}
 
 

 

 

 

 

 
 
 
 
 
1
if(matrixHelp[i][j] > 0 and matrixHelp[j][i] > 0){
2
    A = A + 1
3
}
4
if(matrixHelp[i][j] > 2){
5
    B = B + 1
6
}
 
 

 

 

 

 

 
 
 
 
 
1
if(i < j){
2
    if(matrixHelp[i][j] > 0 and matrixHelp[j][i] > 0){
3
       A = A + 1
4
    }
5
    if(matrixHelp[i][j] > 2){
6
       B = B + 1
7
    }
8
}
 
 

 

 

 

 

 
 
 
 
 
1
if(i < j){
2
    if(matrixHelp[i][j] > 0 and matrixHelp[j][i] > 0){
3
       A = A + 1
4
    }
5
}
6
if(matrixHelp[i][j] > 2){
7
    B = B + 1
8
}
 
 

 

 

 

 
 

 

Question (5-8)
The following table contains information regarding books in a library. Each entry in the table corresponds to a book and is authored by at least two authors. There is a pool of n authors, each author being assigned a unique index between 0 and n − 1. There are M books in total.

The table is represented by a dictionary named books, with the keys as serial numbers and values as the corresponding list of authors. Assume that books has already been computed. For example, we have: books[0] = [0, 2, 3]. Consider the followig question.

 
5 points
 

4.The following pseudocode generates a graph G from books. Each node corresponds to an author. There is an edge between two different authors i and j if they have co-authored a book, and the edge is labeled with the number of books they have co-authored. Choose the correct code fragment to complete the following pseudocode.

 
 
 
 
1
matrix = createMatrix(n, n)
2
foreach i in keys(books){
3
    foreach j in books[i]{
4
        foreach k in books[i]{
5
           ***********************
6
            *** Fill the code ***
7
           ***********************
8
        }
9
    }
10
}
 
 

 

 

 

 
 
 
 
 
1
matrix[j][k] = matrix[j][k] + 1
 
 

 

 

 

 

 
 
 
 
 
1
if(j != k){
2
    matrix[j][k] = matrix[j][k] + 1
3
}
 
 

 

 

 

 

 
 
 
 
 
1
if(j != k){
2
    matrix[j][k] = matrix[j][k] + 1
3
    matrix[k][j] = matrix[k][j] + 1
4
}
 
 

 

 

 

 

 
 
 
 
 
1
matrix[j][k] = matrix[j][k] + 1
2
matrix[k][j] = matrix[k][j] + 1
 
 

 

 

 

 
 
5 points
 

5.The following pseudocode creates adjacency matrix matrix2 of another graph H from books. For two different authors i and j, what does the value matrix2[i][j] represent at the end of the execution?

 
 
 
 
1
matrix2 = createMatrix(n, n)
2
foreach j in rows(matrix2){
3
    foreach k in columns(matrix2){
4
        matrix2[j][k] = []
5
    }
6
}
7
foreach i in keys(books){
8
    foreach j in book[i]{
9
        foreach k in books[i]{
10
            foreach h in books[i]{
11
                if(j != k and j != h and k != h and not member(matrix2[j][k], h)){
12
                    matrix2[j][k] = matrix2[j][k] ++ [h]
13
                    matrix2[k][j] = matrix2[k][j] ++ [h]
14
                }
15
            }
16
        }
17
    }
18
}
 
 

 

 

List of authors who have co-authored a book with both i and j

 

List of authors who have co-authored a book with either i or j

 

List of authors who have co-authored at least two book with both i and j

 

List of authors who have co-authored at least two book with either i or j

 

 
 
5 points

6.Which of the following combinations of entries in matrix and matrix2 is possible for two different authors i and j? It is Multiple Select Question (MSQ).

matrix[i] [j] = 0 and matrix2[i] [j] = [ ]

 

 

matrix[i][j] = 0 and matrix2[i][j] 

≠

= [ ]

 

 

matrix[i][j] > 0 and matrix2[i][j] = [ ]

 

 

matrix[i][j] > 0 and matrix2[i][j] 

≠

= [ ]

 

 

 
 
5 points

Consider the matrices matrix and matrix2 constructed in the previous questions.

findAuthor(matrix) finds an author who has the maximum number of co-authors. Choose the correct implementation of the procedure findAuthor. It is a Multiple Select Question.

 

 
 
 
 
 
1
Procedure findAuthor(M)
2
    Max = 0
3
    A = 0

Question (9-10)

The following pseudocode is executing using the “Shopping bills” dataset. Each customer is being assigned a unique index between 0 and n − 1. Dictionary D has already been computed with keys as index and values as list of distinct shops visited by the corresponding customer. Assume that there exists a procedure intersection which takes two lists as input and outputs another list which contains the common elements in the input lists.

 
 
 
 
1
n = length(keys(D))
2
matrix = createMatrix(n, n)
3
foreach i in rows(matrix){
4
    foreach j in columns(matrix){
5
        if(i != j){
6
            matrix[i][j] = intersection(D[i], D[j])
7
        }
8
        else{
9
            matrix[i][j] = []
10
        }
11
    }
12
}
 
 

 

 
5 points
 

Consider the adjacency matrix matrix constructed above. Assume that there exists a procedure removeDuplicate which receives a list as input and removes all duplicate elements in the list. When will findGoodSet(matrix) return True?

 
 
 
 
1
Procedure findGoodSet(M)
2
    foreach i in rows(M){
3
        foreach j in columns(M){
4
            foreach h in rows(M){
5
                list1 = []
6
                if(length(M[i][j]) == 1 and member(D[h], first(M[i][j]))){
7
                    list1 = list1 ++ M[i][j]
8
                }
9

10
                    list1 = list1 ++ M[i][h]
11
                }
12

13

14
                }
15

16

17
                    return(True)
18
                }
19
            }

        }
21
    }
22
    return(False)
23
End findGoodSet
 
 

 

 

If there exists three customers who have visited all three shops.

 

If there exist three customers such that every pair of customers among them have visited only one and the same shop in common.

 

If there exists three customers who have visited exactly one shop.

 

If there exists three customers where each pair among them have visited exactly one shop in common.
